messages: 3975935bcb2867ad501e2a76c1033180 (04:40): is seeing "Enabled." on a service log in /var/svc/log that coindes with every reboot mean that svcadm clear/enable was typed after each reboot or that is what happens normally when the service is restarted?

c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (04:56): so, I've been thinking of setting up a mail server. Something secure, fast and updatable (not too much work)...any recommendations?
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (04:56): but i just thought of the reason why the 14th would be a good day
c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (04:56): within linux, mail toasters are a snap...solaris is another thing though
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (04:57): its the aniversary of the release of  opensolaris
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (04:57): if you can wait a month, i would go with solaris 10.. if not grab solaris express  b39 seems pretty stable
c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (04:58): jamesd: need to go into production
c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (04:58): jamesd: I'll wait I guess
c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (04:58): windows 2003 + exchange 2003 is pretty slick
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (04:59): i've haven't heard anything to say its not production ready... ZFS is really rock stable
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (04:59): Netwolf, only if you don't have to back up and reconfigure it every 2 days
c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (04:59): and for some reason, the smb implementation of windows native as faster than samba on linux or solaris
c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (04:59): jamesd: I haven't touched the server (with the exception of php update = 30 minutes) since two months

c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (05:01): jamesd: Once setup (Active Directory, Filestore, Messaging, URL Scan, MODX CMS and Brightmail w/Mysql) it's been running non-stop for two months...no downtime so far
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:01): lucky.. you must be a damm good administrator... i 've heard lots of horror stories
c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (05:01): the most painful experience I had was to install solaris with 12 zones (each for a separate use) and spend over 4 days smpatch update

3975935bcb2867ad501e2a76c1033180 (05:04): well google/yahoo mysql gotchas...  there's a site that lists a whole lot of mysql gotchas...  stuff that's just horrible...  but lots of that has been fixed in mysql version 5
3975935bcb2867ad501e2a76c1033180 (05:05): but the thing is what people use myql for could very well be served just as well by if not better with a bdb or some other flat files
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:05): andy so?  it has a few  bugs.. what doesn't... if you don't hit the code path with the bugs or you work around them... life goes on.

7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:08): andy_, just like  beta vs. vhs, the one that got the best number of users.. wins... sorry but mysql is used by most if not all ready made php apps, sure they may support others, but they are not as well tested... if your writing your own code you can use postgres, but if you are lazy  use what your packages support
c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (05:08): jamesd: aye

c0e501eaf5b17bbe7314404b6854421a (05:09): AIX is pretty cool actually

7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:27): FlashHater, nope.. closest thing is systemtap.. and its not stable in the least and has about 30% of its functonality on a good day ( one that it doesn't kill the system in the proccess)
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:27): solaris has more letters in it's name that linux, so it's obviously better
8458c1e5371d3ea3216c538d96bb6154 (05:28): I <3 my linux box too much to part with it
8458c1e5371d3ea3216c538d96bb6154 (05:28): I should port pacman to solaris
8458c1e5371d3ea3216c538d96bb6154 (05:29): but then I'd have to rebuild all of the packages
8458c1e5371d3ea3216c538d96bb6154 (05:29): and I switched away from gentoo to avoid compilation
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:31): i think it is good to see that Sun is diversifying and releasing new products!
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:31): http://www.docbert.org/tmp/sun.jpg
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:33): nice... i want one of those.. maybe for for nominating people, and can i get some of that solaris laudry soap as well
8458c1e5371d3ea3216c538d96bb6154 (05:41): hey, is there any way in solaris to trace signals (SIGKILL in particular) back to their source?
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:44): FlashHater, of course dtrace
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:44): brendan g's tool kit has that
8458c1e5371d3ea3216c538d96bb6154 (05:44): I wish that there was a way to do that in linux without writing 4 pages of C
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:45): dtrace -qn 'syscall::kill:entry { printf("%Y: PID %d (%s) sent signal %d to PID %d\n",wallclocktime, pid, execname, arg1, arg0);} '
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:46): (that's the quick-and-dirty version - it doesn't check that the signal actually worked)
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:46): brendan g's is 62 lines including  comprehensive  comments
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:46): the full version i've got here (monitor 1 PID only, only shows successful, signals, etc) is about 8 lines long
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:48): http://www.docbert.org/tmp/dt.txt
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:49): try doing that without dtrace!
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:49): (you can do it with BSM Audit, but it's ugly)
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:49): docL its only 2 lines of code, and a kernel recompile and install ;-p
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (05:49): and dont forget the backout :)
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (05:51): systemtap may be able to handle such a simple task...  most of the time...  but i wouldn't want to run it on a prodcution system with no backups
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (06:14): http://uadmin.blogspot.com/2005/09/systemtap-links.html <--- links to there home page, and email acrives and dtrace comparisons
